Posts.Content: Glad that everything went well! Hubby was in the best of spirits afterwards. Just so glad to get it over with. Our kids came up that evening to see him and were expecting him to be feeling poorly. Ha - he was almost running around the hospital corridors feeling wonderful. Of course he had pain meds on board, but really and truly he came thru with flying colors. I'm sure you will too as you are young and fit! You can go walking the streets of New York next!
Posts.Signature: Wife of hubby age-60, physical in July, '13 DRE normal, psa elevated, off to uroligist 6 of 12 positive cores (aug 2013) 4+4 gs, in two cores, bilateral psa 5.2 (July 2013) psa 3.1 (Jan. 2012) psa 2.3 (2011) psa 2.0 (2010) psa 1.8 (2009) psa 1.6 (2008 T1c, bone scan & MRI clear Family hist. (dad & unc.) RALP 10/30/13 Post surgery upgraded to GS 9. (10% of gland-5) Early invasion of left seminal vesicle PT3b upgraded Radiation 6 mts after surgery. Done.

Posts.Title: Post Op - Day 1

Posts.Content: Hubby has been seeing the oncologist at UofM. He has been monitoring him over the last year. PSA is on a steady rise. Two scans later bone and abdominal (February and September) we have located where it has spread. Small spot lit up, lower back, in the sacrum. While at last appointment, hubby was asked if he would be interested in doing a clinical research trial. It could help him (or so he said) to locate any other areas of concern. The trial is called PyL. There are a few articles on the net that we have been reading about. It involves them injecting, and doing a different kind of scan. Also a bone biopsy to study. Although it may be beneficial, hubby is leaning towards NOT being in this trial. I didn't think a bone biopsy sounded like fun. Anyone else do one of these? If only one spot shows up, doctor said they could radiate it. We are very doubtful that there is only one. We return to UofM next week, with a decision. Looks like hormones are next.
Posts.Signature: Wife of hubby age-60, physical in July, '13 DRE normal, psa elevated, off to uroligist 6 of 12 positive cores (aug 2013) 4+4 gs, in two cores, bilateral psa 5.2 (July 2013) psa 3.1 (Jan. 2012) psa 2.3 (2011) psa 2.0 (2010) psa 1.8 (2009) psa 1.6 (2008 T1c, bone scan & MRI clear Family hist. Posts.Title: Back again - PSA on the rise.

Posts.Content: 4 mts after surgery psa 0.1 (uroligist appt.) Feb. '14 7 mts after surgery psa 0.1 (uroligist appt.) May. '14 8 mts after surgery approx 40 days of radiation 11 mts after surg/radiation psa 0.1 (radiation oncologist) Sept. '14 13 mts after surg/radiation psa 0.1 (uroligist) Nov. 14 18 mts appt. psa 0.1 (uroligist) May '15 2 yrs. psa 0.1 Nov. '15 2.5 yrs. psa 0.2. Ok this is what I dug up this AM. Yes I go to all of his appointments! It seems like over kill to me to jump on the hormones, but what do I know. A medical oncologist? I will get busy and investigate. We are in mid-Michigan. Close to Ann Arbor.
Posts.Signature: Wife of hubby age-60, physical in July, '13 DRE normal, psa elevated, off to uroligist 6 of 12 positive cores (aug 2013) 4+4 gs, in two cores, bilateral psa 5.2 (July 2013) psa 3.1 (Jan. 2012) psa 2.3 (2011) psa 2.0 (2010) psa 1.8 (2009) psa 1.6 (2008 T1c, bone scan & MRI clear Family hist. Posts.Title: 2.5 yrs later - psa rises.

Posts.Content: Hubby saw uroligist for his 6 mt check up., and his psa has risen. Every time we went it was good news, until NOW. Doctor said we could do one of two things. Check it again in 2 mts just to see if it continues to rise, or start hormone therapy. Hubby right then and there said hormone therapy. I came home and read the chapter in Walsh book, and he doesn't lean towards hormone therapy at this time even when psa rises. Later yes, when things really RISE. We were very hopeful that perhaps the surgery and radiation had killed the beast. So much for our positive thinking. Any insight? Hubby read the part about 'man boobs' so he is going for radiation on his chest. (need to change the info at the bottom after I remember how. Hubby did radiation 6 mts after surgery.

Posts.Title: 2.5 yrs later - psa rises.

Posts.Content: His surgery is at 7 am. I had read 3 hrs and just now 5 hr surgery. Wow, that is alot of time to be OUT. Hoping they don't deprive the brain of oxygen. THAT happened to my MIL. It wasn't good. (open heart surgery) Since he has to be there at 530 am I was thinking of leaving when they take him down to surgery. Coming home, eating, coffee, shower, and head back up to hospital. It's going to be a longggg day. Hospital is 10-15 min from home. I don't do well sitting for long periods of time and I'll be at the hospital most of the afternoon.

Posts.Title: Questions to ask surgeon

Posts.Content: We have a son who is 29. Hubby feels he is doomed to get PC. (hubby, FIL, and an uncle all on his side have it) but I keep saying maybe he will NOT get PC because he could get my side of the family genetics and there is no PC. Anything is possible right? I just don't want our son to worry about this at the prime of his life. Yes he will be checked early.

Posts.Title: 6 months and Mexico

Posts.Content: I will read up on the links posted- THANK YOU. The doctor does want bloodwork one week before his appt in February - so not really sure what his plans are. He just seemed to be going towards radiation regardless. (?) I could of misunderstood after we heard the bad news, anything is possible. I am the positive one here between DH and I. Focusing on the negative margins, and no lymph node involvement. Trying hard to keep the man UP and focused on recovery to get back to some kind of normalcy here. Perhaps when he gets his PSA checked in February, there will be no trace of that little SOB. That would be nice. Maybe for once when we go to uroligist's office, we could get good news. I WILL STAY FOCUSED ON THAT!

Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: I am staying positive that this is the hand we have been dealt with and we go from here. DH is of course not happy for fear that there is still cancer in there. He wanted the surgery to get it out of his body. Now he waits just like before. The doctor seemed like radiation would be done, no mention of waiting around for the PSA at 3 mts. It does make me wonder. I have the path report and I will look at it more in depth. Some I can understand, some I cannot. How bad is this? Anyone else been thru this with radiation. Is this what is called salvage?
Posts.Signature: Wife of hubby age-60, physical in July, '13 DRE normal, psa elevated, off to uroligist 6 of 12 positive cores (aug 2013) 4+4 gs, in two cores, bilateral psa 5.2 (July 2013) psa 3.1 (Jan. 2012) psa 2.3 (2011) psa 2.0 (2010) psa 1.8 (2009) psa 1.6 (2008 T1c, bone scan & MRI clear Family hist. (dad & unc.) RALP 10/30/13 Post surgery upgraded to GS 9. (10% of gland-5) Early invasion of left seminal vesicle PT3b upgraded Radiation 6 mts after surgery. Done.
Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: Eight days after RALP, off to doc we went yesterday for removal of cath and path report. 30% of gland was malignant, both sides, and DH went from a gs of 8 (biopsy) to a 9. Also path report shows foci of extracapsular extension and early invasion of the left seminal vesicle. Lymph nodes were negative, all surgical margins free of tumor. So in 3 months, he heads down the radiation road to clean up the area. Any words of wisdom? This is all so surreal to me. I cannot imagine all the men out there that do not do annual visits with their doctors. This cancer would of just taken over DH if he wasn't the proactive type guy. I am still a bit shocked about all of this. DH is just beside himself.

(dad & unc.) RALP 10/30/13 Post surgery upgraded to GS 9. (10% of gland-5) Early invasion of left seminal vesicle PT3b upgraded Radiation 6 mts after surgery. Done.
Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: Eight days after RALP, off to doc we went yesterday for removal of cath and path report. 30% of gland was malignant, both sides, and DH went from a gs of 8 (biopsy) to a 9. Also path report shows foci of extracapsular extension and early invasion of the left seminal vesicle. Lymph nodes were negative, all surgical margins free of tumor. So in 3 months, he heads down the radiation road to clean up the area. Any words of wisdom? This is all so surreal to me. I cannot imagine all the men out there that do not do annual visits with their doctors. This cancer would of just taken over DH if he wasn't the proactive type guy. I am still a bit shocked about all of this. DH is just beside himself.
Posts.Signature: Wife of hubby age-60, physical in July, '13 DRE normal, psa elevated, off to uroligist 6 of 12 positive cores (aug 2013) 4+4 gs, in two cores, bilateral psa 5.2 (July 2013) psa 3.1 (Jan. 2012) psa 2.3 (2011) psa 2.0 (2010) psa 1.8 (2009) psa 1.6 (2008 T1c, bone scan & MRI clear Family hist. (dad & unc.) RALP 10/30/13 Post surgery upgraded to GS 9. (10% of gland-5) Early invasion of left seminal vesicle PT3b upgraded Radiation 6 mts after surgery. Done.
Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: I am staying positive that this is the hand we have been dealt with and we go from here. DH is of course not happy for fear that there is still cancer in there. He wanted the surgery to get it out of his body. Now he waits just like before. The doctor seemed like radiation would be done, no mention of waiting around for the PSA at 3 mts. It does make me wonder. I have the path report and I will look at it more in depth. Some I can understand, some I cannot. How bad is this? Anyone else been thru this with radiation. Is this what is called salvage?

Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: I cannot imagine a partner doing that either. If they did, it seems like they'd have alot to live with after that. I'm sure it happens but more than likely if it does, there was much more involved than the PCa.

Posts.Title: PCA and Divorce

Posts.Content: Welcome! I've been reading on this board for a few months since my hubby was dx in August. He had the RALP surgery also, two days after you. He was able to come home the next day, but didn't have the issues that you did. Lucky You! NOT! Hope all went well and that your path report is decent. DH's appt is on Thurs for cath removal and results. Then onto the next journey and hump to get over (incontinence). Other members will be here soon! They are so helpful! I'm just a newbie too offering you a warm welcome!

Posts.Title: New to the Forum... Just had RP

Posts.Content: Hello - It is w/ deep regret that I have to be here. No offense. Hubby has been dx w/ Pca. It's not good. I have been reading and researching myself. Hubby doesn't surf the web. I will fill in the information I have on hand as soon as I figure out how to do it. Hubby goes faithfully to his doctor yearly. He is 60. His Dad had Pca at 60 also. He did not die from it. Psa was 5.3. Up from last year of 3.1. Saw urilogist, he did biopsy. Six out of twelve spots were positive. All scans came back good. Appt. today with uroligist. He is referring him to the specialist to see if he is a candidate for surgery via robotic. Grade was HIGH End. Staging T1C. Gleason 4+4. Bilateral. I bought the Walsh book today. Scared out of my gord. How bad is this? Lay it on me.

Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: Congrats Dayglo! When is the next check? 3 mts?
Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: I personally try and be grateful for what we have. Hubby on the other hand always looks at his glass as half empty. I think the older we get the more we are exposed to sickness and dying. I try and not focus on the negatives. We were just with friends over the weekend and the guys were constantly switching the conversation over to health. I can't do that! Here I was trying to switch it back. I finally left the room and ate cookies in the kitchen. Cripe, I'm going to get FAT! Be thankful Nancy for what you have with hubby. You are blessed and so is he.
